Event Space and Graph Reduction

Source: vignettes/Event-Space-and-Graph-Reduction.Rmd
Event-Space-and-Graph-Reduction.Rmd

Event Space

Given event space ùîº\mathbb{E} with kk independent event groupings: ùîº:=eÃÇ1+eÃÇ2+eÃÇ3+‚ãØ+eÃÇk \mathbb{E}:=\hat{e}_1 + \hat{e}_2+ \hat{e}_3 + \cdots + \hat{e}_k and corresponding heterogeneous data tables (ùîª:=D1,D2,D3,‚ãØ,Dk\mathbb{D} :=D_1,D_2,D_3,\cdots,D_k) each having a ‚Äújoin-key‚Äù (JJ, a column or column tuple shared across ùîª\mathbb{D}), an event vector (Vq‚Üí\overrightarrow{V_q}) is formed having values indicating the existence or absence of selection over DkD_k predicated on qq unique values ‚àÄJ\forall J:

$$ \overrightarrow{V_q}:= \exists \sigma_{j_q \in J}(D_k) \Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_1 + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_2 + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_3 + \cdots + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_k \\ q :=\text{ the q}^{th}\text{ distinct value in }J\enspace \forall \mathbb{D} \\ \sigma_{j_q \in J}(D_k) \equiv \dot{D_{qk}}:=\text{ predicated selection operation in a relational algebra context} $$

From each Vq‚Üí\overrightarrow{V_q}, qq subsets over ùîª\mathbb{D} are derived as Œìq:=Dkq|Vq‚Üí‚â†‚àÖ\Gamma_q:=D_{k_q}|\overrightarrow{V_q}\ne\emptyset. The number of records (nn) resulting from selection across the data sets can be represented as an array of row vectors:

$$ \Gamma_q\longrightarrow \text{Distinct row counts over}\dot{D_{k_q}}\Rightarrow\begin{array} ((n_{11}&n_{12}&n_{13}&\cdots&n_{1k})\\ (n_{21}&n_{22}&n_{23}&\cdots&n_{2k})\\ (n_{31}&n_{32}&n_{33}&\cdots&n_{3k})\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ (n_{q1}&n_{q2}&n_{q3}&\cdots&n_{qk}) \end{array} $$

Graph Reduction

Next, considering a fully-connected graph having Œ≤\beta nodes and number of edges given as follows: K‚Üíf(Œ≤):=(Œ≤2)‚â°Œ≤(Œ≤‚àí1)2 \begin{align} K\rightarrow f(\beta) := {\beta\choose2} \equiv \frac{\beta(\beta-1)}{2} \end{align} and taking into account that event.vectors creates separate graphs for each qq, the number of edges per fully-connected graph GqG_q is given as follows:

$$ \beta_q := \sum_{i=1}^q\Gamma_i \Rightarrow (\beta_1,\beta_2,\beta_3,\cdots,\beta_q)\\ K_q \rightarrow f(\beta_q) := {\beta_q\choose2} $$ , which is also the number of comparisons to be carried out computationally.

KqK_q can be reduced by projecting a set of logically-reduced predicates (as mentioned earlier) to interim results before creating each of the qq graphs:

$$ P_m:m\text{ predicates}\Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_m\\ \dot\beta_q:=\forall i \in q\rightarrow\Gamma_i*\Pi (P_m|\dot D_{k_i})\\ 0 \le \dot\beta_q\le\beta_q $$ This can quickly result in not only edge reduction but graph elimination for each qq (Œìq\Gamma_q can easily become sparse). Trial and error may needed to fine-tune how graphs are generated as well as improve execution performance which is why the graph.control argument is provided for event.vectors::make.evs_universe() to allow for operating on graphs after the fact.

Developed by Chionesu George.
